titleStmt.title: Deep Learning-Inspired Message Passing Algorithm for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cognitive Radio Networks

affiliation.orgName: Yang and G. Gui are with College of Telecommunication and Information Engineering
Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications. M. Liu, T. Song, and J. Hu are with National Mobile Communications Research Laboratory
Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications

analytic.title: Deep Learning-Inspired Message Passing Algorithm for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cognitive Radio Networks

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TVT.2018.2883669, IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology received XXX, XX, 2018.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Energy efficiency (EE) and spectrum efficiency (SE) have received significant attentions on optimizing the network performance in cognitive radio networks. In this paper, an EE+SE tradeoff based target is considered for the primary users (PUs) and the secondary users (SUs). First of all, considering the orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA)-based resource allocation (RA) for the underlying SUs, we formulate an objective function through minimizing a weighted sum of the secondary interference power, where the network performance of both PUs and SUs are guaranteed by the constraints on quality of service (QoS), power consumption and data rate. However, it is a NP-hard problem. In order to solve it, we propose a damped three dimensional (D3D) message-passing algorithm (MPA) based on deep learning. Specifically, a feed-forward neural network is devised and an analogous back propagation (ABP) algorithm is developed to learn the optimal parameters of the D3D-MPA. To improve the computational efficiency of the allocation and the learning, a suboptimal RA scheme is deduced based on a damped two dimensional (D2D) MPA. Finally, simulation results are provided to confirm the effectiveness of our proposed scheme.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: In recent decades, with the rapidly growing rate demands of various wireless application types, cognitive radio network (CRN) [1] has been proposed and well-investigated to alleviate the spectrum scarcity problem. Additionally, a large number of new wireless systems and technologies have emerged, such as device to device (D2D) networks [2], internet of vehicle (IoV) networks [3], massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems [4], mmWave communications [5], full duplex (FD) transmission [6], energy efficient (EE) technology [7], multisensor fault diagnosis [8], and artificial intelligence (AI) [9]- [12]. To improve the quality of communications and the spectrum efficiency (SE) in current and future networks, it is necessary to perform more research on applying CRNs with more advanced technologies [13]- [16]. To this day, many innovative studies on IoV-based mobile CRNs, massive MIMO-based CRNs and mmWave-based CRNs have emerged, focusing on spectrum sensing, resource allocation, and antenna selection [17]- [25].

It can be found that, to address the licensed spectrum sharing problem in CRNs, resource allocation (RA) for the underlaying secondary users (SUs) is a hot topic. However, existing RA schemes only considered the efficiencies of the SUs, ignoring that the secondary EE+SE improvements always come at a cost of EE+SE decrease in the primary system.

Moreover, RA optimization with various constraints usually is a NP-hard problem. To solve the problem, traditional algorithms have been developed, such as Hungarian algorithm, genetic algorithm and ant colony algorithm. However, these algorithms are still hard to perform real-time scenarios with optimal solutions. To realize the users' communication requirements, deep learning is considered as a promising track. Specifically, it has been applied to deal with heterogeneous networks [26]- [28] and intelligent traffic control [29].

In this paper, we proposed a novel EE+SE tradeoff based RA method for the downlinks of cellular CRN. Different from traditional understanding of the relationships between PUs and SUs, we create a more friendly and flexible spectrum sharing mechanism based on our previous work [31]. Focused on the RA scheme for CRNs as well, our previous work [31] aimed to minimize the total secondary interference power introduced to the PUs. In other words, that work is to depress the influence of SUs on the primary transmissions and protect the capacity of the PUs. By introducing adaptive weights to the secondary interference power, the efficiency tradeoff scheme for the SUs and the PUs is achieved. Further, to cope with the complicated min-sum optimization problem effectively [35]- [42], a damped three-dimensional message passing algorithm (D3D-MPA) is developed.

Inspired by the learned approximate message passing algorithm (LAMPA) for compressive sensing [30], [43], we apply deep learning to our D3D-MPA based on a feed-forward neural network. Firstly, we derive the neural network based scheme to solve the RA problem. Secondly, learnable parameters of the scheme are formulated. Thirdly, the corresponding deep learning network is illustrated, and the analogous back propagation (ABP) algorithm is proposed to learn the optimal parameters. Additionally, the flow-chart of our deep learning based RA scheme is depicted. Alternatively, a simplified MPA is provided to solve the problem sub-optimally with a lower cost of learning. Simulation experiments are conducted to confirm that the proposed deep learning based RA scheme can obtain more satisfying performances in terms of the EE+SE tradeoff between SUs and PUs, while with lower computing complexity and learning cost.
The reminder of the rest paper is organized as follows.

In Section II, we describe the system model and formulate the EE+SE tradeoff based RA problem. The D3D-MPA based scheme is proposed to solve the NP-hard problem with three steps in Section III. The deep learning algorithms are developed to optimize the neural network parameters of the scheme in Section IV. Further, a simplified learning MPA based RA scheme with lower computational complexity and learning cost is provided in Section V. We evaluate the performances of our schemes in Section VI and conclude our work in Section VII.
The key mathematical notations used in our paper are listed in Table I.

div.head: II. SYSTEM MODEL AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: In this paper, we focus on a system model where orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA)-based PUs pairs and cellular SUs coexist through the spectrum underlaying. Without loss of generality, the model is illustrated in Fig. 1. As shown, there are N SUs and M pairs of PUs in the coverage of the secondary base station (SBS).

Additionally, the number of available subchannels is assumed sufficient for the SUs, and denoted as Z 0 . G i,z and G j,z denote the transmission power gain for the pair P U i and SU j on subchannel z, respectively. Similarly, g i,z and g z,j denote the mutual interfering power gain between SU j and P U i on subchannel z. In this paper we only consider the secondary downlinks, thus the SBS-related gains G j,z and g j,z are equal for all the SUs. Transmission gains for P U i and SU j on subchannel z g i,z , g j,z
Interfering gains between P U i and SU j on subchannel z P S j,z , x j,z Power and assignment factor for SU j on subchannel z I j,z
Interference power from SU j to P U i on subchannel z I P z,j Message from function node W j to x j,z mCz→x j,z
Message from function node Cz to x j,z mS→x j,z

Message from function node S to x j,z µx j,z →W j Normalized message from x j,z to function node W j µx j,z →Cz Normalized message from x j,z to function node Cz µx j,z →S Normalized message from x j,z to function node S µW j →x j,z
Normalized message from function node W j to x j,z µCz→x j,z
Normalized message from function node Cz to x j,z µS→x j,z
Normalized message from function node S to x j,z {v xW j,f }s The
div.formula: s th smallest {µx j,f → W f + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f } {v xC l,z }s The sth-smallest µx l,z → Cz Z 0
div.p: The subchannel set including all the subchannels Z 0-z
The subchannel set excluding the subchannel z
div.formula: {vA xS l,f } Z 0-z ,N The set of µx l,f → S when x l,f belongs to Z 0-z {vB xS l,f } Z 0 ,N
div.p: The set of µx l,f → S when x l,f belongs to Z 0 τ j,z
The marginalization of x j,z ε
Damped parameters for the t th iteration ε 2D

div.head: T ied
div.p: Damped parameter for the D2D MPA T Total iterative times of message passing T *
Iterative times of message passing for convergency xj,z
The assignment result of SU j on subchannel z P AC total Total Power required by the admitted SUs P1 : min
div.formula: Z 0 z=1 ρ z N j=1 ϕ j ω j,z I j,z x j,z s. t. I j,z ≤ I * z , ∀z, j (C1) γ j,z ≥ γ * j , ∀z, j (C2) R j ≥ R * j , ∀j (C3) Z 0 z=1 N j=1 P S j,z ≤ P max (C4) N j=1 x j,z ≤ 1, ∀z(C5)
P S j,z ≥ 0, ∀z, j (C7)
div.p: Since the objective of our scheme is to balance the EE+SE between PUs and SUs, the optimization problem is formulated as (P1), where P S j,z is the power allocated to SU j on subchannel z and x j,z is the binary assignment factor for SU j on subchannel z. Correspondingly, I j,z is the interference power introduced by SU j on subchannel z, γ j,z is the signal to interference and noise radio (SINR) for the SU j on subchannel z, and R j is the sum rate of SU j . Hence, constraint (C1) means that the interference introduced by the SUs must be no more than the thresholds I * z on subchannel z. Similarly, (C2) and (C3) denote that the SUs' QoS and sum rate is not lower than their demands, in which they are represented as γ * j and R * j , respectively. The total power constraint is given in (C4), where P max is the maximum power that can be allocated to the SUs.

Notably, w j,z is considered as the efficiency tradeoff weights for SU j on subchannel z. Therefore, the optimization objective is weighted interference minimization (WIM). Since the relationship between the interference introduced and power consumed by SU j on subchannel z is expressed as
div.formula: P S j,z = I j,z /g j,z ,(1)
div.p: the weighted interference-based objective can also reduce the SUs' power consumption effectively.

In particular, if each w j,z is taken as 1/g j,z , the optimization objective will become power optimization (PM), while if they are taken as 1, the objective will become interference optimization (IM). Therefore, when w j,z is taken between 1 and 1/g j,z the tradeoff between the total secondary interference introduced and the total secondary power consumed can be achieved, which is equivalent to the EE+SE tradeoff between PUs and SUs. Moreover, with diverse weights, the tradeoff can be more elaborate for individual SUs on each subchannel.

Meanwhile, the fairness factors are applicable in the optimizing target. With the fairness factor ϕ j , EE can be better balanced among SUs, and with the fairness factor ρ z , EE+SE can be better balanced among PUs.
To save space, all the related expressions and additional deductions for (P1) are omitted, which can be achieved by referring to our previous work in [31].

div.head: III. A MESSAGE PASSING-BASED SOLUTION
div.p: To solve (P1), we propose a stepwise method which is composed with power initialization, subchannel assignment, and access control. Each step is presented as follows.
Step 1. Power initialization.

The requesting SUs firstly sense the interference power from the PUs on the available subchannels and obtain the results as I P z,j . Combining (C1) and (C2), the power allocated for SU j on subchannel z needs to satisfy
div.formula: γ * j I P z,j G j,z ≤ P S j,z ≤ I * z /g j,z .(2)
div.p: For SU j , the subchannel z is available if
div.formula: γ * j I P z,j G j,z ≤ I * z /g j,z ,(3)
div.p: According to Eq. ( 3), on an accessible subchannel of SU j , if the allocated power is equal to that for the SINR demand, the interference power introduced will not exceed the corresponding threshold. As a result, the initial power for the SUs on their accessible subchannels is considered as:
div.formula: P S * j,z = γ * j I P z,j G j,z .(4)
div.p: When Eq. (3) fails to be satisfied, the SUs cannot use this subchannel. However, in order to apply MPA, the power initialization needs be accomplished for SUs on the inaccessible subchannels as well. If the inaccessible subchannels are allocated, outages can be executed according to the criterion as:
div.formula: g j,z P S * j,z > I * z .(5)
div.p: To make the problem tractable, we further introduce a virtual user to reserve the unassigned subchannels. According to (C3), the minimum number of subchannels required for all the SUs can be computed as
div.formula: Z = N j=1 R * j B 0 log(1 + γ * j ) = N j=1 Z j ,(6)
div.p: For simplicity, we assume Z j is a positive integer. Then, (C3) can be transformed as an equality constraint on the number of required subchannel as follows:
where the (N + 1) th SU is the virtual user. And the number of its requiring subchannels are Z N +1 = Z 0 -Z . For computing, the virtual power for the (N + 1) th SU can be initialized as:
div.formula: P S * N +1,z = P huge , ∀z,(8)
div.p: where P huge = χP max and χ is a coefficient far greater than 1. In summary, the formulated problem can be transformed as:
div.formula: P2 : min Z 0 z=1 N +1 j=1 ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z x j,z s. t. Z 0 z=1 x j,z = Z j , ∀j (C1 ) N +1 j=1 x j,z ≤ 1, ∀z (C2 ) Z 0 z=1 N j=1 x j,z P S * j,z ≤ P max , (C3 ) N +1 j=1 Z j = Z 0 , (C4 ) x j,z ∈ {0, 1}, ∀z, j
div.p: where I S * j,z = g j,z P S * j,z .
Step 2. Subchannel assignment.
Referring to [40], to solve (P2) via MPA, the constraintsrelated cost functions need to be formulated. Thus, we introduce the cost functions W j (x), C z (x) and S(x)
div.formula: (j = 1, • • •, N + 1; z = 1, • • •, Z 0 ) as: W j (x) =    Z 0 z=1 ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z (x j,z ) if Z 0 z=1 x j,z = Z j +∞ otherwise,(9)
C z (x) =    0 if N +1 j=1 x j,z ≤ 1 +∞ otherwise,(10)
S(x) =    0 if Z 0 z=1 N j=1 x j,z P S * j,z ≤ P max +∞ otherwise.(11)
div.p: Correspondingly, (P2) can be represented as:

Then, the min-sum problem can be depicted as a factor graph model in Fig. 2. Commonly, the circles are denoted as the assignment variables x j,z , and the squares are denoted as the cost functions. Between these variable nodes and function nodes, the bidirectional 3D messages are iteratively passing on the depicted surfaces S1, S2 and S3.

Since the virtual SU is designed for gathering all the unused subchannels, these subchannels can not be used by the actual SUs. Additionally, the power allocated to the virtual SU's subchannels are always zero. As a result, the subchannel assignment constraints (C2') are valid for all the SUs, including the virtual SU, while the power budget constraint (C3') is only established for the N requesting SUs. Therefore, no messages can be passed on the edges between node S and the variable nodes x N +1 . In order to uniformly formulating the messages, we preset the messages between nodes x N +1 and S as
div.formula: mx j,z → S (x N +1,z ) ≡ mS → x j,z (x N +1,z ) ≡ 0. (13)
div.p: Thus the message formulations can be concluded as follows. Referring to Eq. ( 6) in [40], the messages transmitted from a variable node to a function node equaled the sum of the messages transmitted from the other function nodes to the variable node. As a result, the messages passed from x j,z is
div.formula: mx j,z → W j (x j,z ) = mC z → x j,z (x j,z ) + mS → x j,z (x j,z ) , (14
mx j,z → C z (x j,z ) = mW j → x j,z (x j,z ) + mS → x j,z (x j,z ) , (15
mx j,z → S (x j,z ) =    mW j → x j,z (x j,z ) +mC z → x j,z (x j,z ) j = N + 1 0 j = N + 1.(16)
div.p: Similarly, the messages passed from the function nodes can be referred to Eq. ( 7) in [40], computed as the minimum message transmitted from other variable nodes adding the local cost of the function node. Therefore, the cost related messages for (P2) are formulated as
div.formula: mW j → x j,z (x j,z ) = min    f =z mx j,f → W j (x j,f ) + Z 0 z=1 ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z (x j,z )    = min f =z mx j,f → W j (x j,f ) + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f (x j,f ) + ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z (x j,z ), s. t. x j,z + f =j x j,f = Z j (17) mC z → x j,z (x j,z ) = min l =j mx l,z → C z (x l,z ), s.t. x j,z + l =j x l,z ≤ 1; (18) mS → x j,z (x j,z ) =      min Z 0 f =1 N l=1 mx l,f → S (x l,f ) j = N + 1 0 j = N + 1 s.t. P S * j,z (x j,z ) + Z 0 f =1 N l=1 P S * l,f (x l,f ) ≤ P max .(19)
div.p: Specifically, for j = N + 1 in Eq. ( 19), if l = j, then f = z, and vice versa. Furthermore, since x j,z is only taken as 0 or 1, we can simplify the vector messages with length 2 by normalizing them into scalar messages. Firstly, the normalized messages from the variable nodes can be defined as Eqs. (20)(21)(22)
div.formula: µx j,z → W j = mx j,z → W j (1) -mx j,z → W j (0), (20) µx j,z → C z = mx j,z → C z (1) -mx j,z → C z (0), (21) µx j,z → S = mx j,z → S(1) -mx j,z → S(0). (22
div.p: According to the normalized messages formulation in Eq. ( 20), Eq. ( 23) can be determined.
div.formula: mx j,f → W j (x j,f ) -mx j,f → W j (0) + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f (x j,f ) = µx j,f → W f + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f if x j,f = 1 0 if x j,f = 0. (23
div.p: Secondly, by subtracting the term
div.formula: f =z,f ∈Z 0 mx j,f → W j (0)
div.p: from both sides of Eq. ( 17), the vector messages from the cost nodes can be transformed as Eq. ( 24). Hence, if x j,z = 1, in Eq. ( 23), the number of x j,f equal to 1 is Z j -1 (f = z); otherwise, the number is Z j .
div.formula: mW j → x j,z (x j,z ) - f =z,f ∈Z 0 mx j,f → W j (0) = min f =z,f ∈Z 0 {mx j,f → W j (x j,f ) -mx j,f → W j (0) + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f (x j,f )} + ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z (x j,z ) s.t. x j,z + f =z,f ∈Z 0 x j,f = Z j (24)
div.p: Referring to [40], we also denote {v xW j,f } s as the s th sorted µx j,f → W f + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f , listed in ascending order with f = z. Then, the messages in Eq. ( 24) can be simplified with different values of the variable node as Eq. ( 25) and Eq. ( 26).
div.formula: mW j → x j,z (1) - f =z,f ∈Z 0 mx j,f → W j (0) = ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z + Zj -1 s=1 {v xW j,f } s ,(25)
mW j → x j,z (0) - f =z,f ∈Z 0 mx j,f → W j (0) = Zj s=1 v xW j,f s .(26)
div.p: Thus, we express the normalized messages for Eq. ( 17) as
div.formula: µW j → x j,z = mW j → x j,z (1) -mW j → x j,z (0),(27)
div.p: then the normalized message from the cost node W j can be recomputed as
div.formula: µW j → x j,z = ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z -{v xW j,f } Zj = ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z -{µx j,f → W f + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f } Zj .(28)
div.p: Thirdly, according to Eq. ( 18), we define {v xC l,z } s as the s th smallest µx l,z → C z . Then, similar deductions are shown as:
div.formula: mC z → x j,z (x j,z ) - l =j mx l,z → C z (0) = min l =j {mx l,z → C z (x l,z ) -mx l,z → C z (0)}, (29
mC z → x j,z (1) - l =j mx l,z → C z (0) = 0, (30
mC z → x j,z (0) - l =j mx l,z → C z (0) = min l =j v xC l,z .(31)
div.p: As a result, the normalized message from the cost node C z can be denoted as
div.formula: µC z → x j,z = mC z → x j,z (1) -mC z → x j,z (0) ,(32)
div.p: and recomputed as:
div.formula: µC z → x j,z = -min l =j v xC l,z = -min l =j µx l,z → C z .(33)
div.p: Finally, the message related to the "gathering node" S is deduced. According to Eq. ( 19), the corresponding message normalization can be computed by the following steps as
div.formula: mS → x j,z (x j,z ) - Z 0 f =1 N l=1 mx l,f → S (0) = min Z 0 f =1 N l=1 {mx l,f → S (x l,f ) -mx l,f → S (0)},(34)
div.p: mS → x j,z (1) -
div.formula: Z 0 f =1 N l=1 mx l,f → S (0) = min f ∈Z 0-z N l=1 {mx l,f → S (x l,f ) -mx l,f → S (0)},(35)
div.p: mS → x j,z (0) -
div.formula: Z 0 f =1 N l=1 mx l,f → S (0) = min f ∈Z 0 N l=1 {mx l,f → S (x l,f ) -mx l,f → S (0)}.(36)
div.p: According to Eq. ( 22), mx l,f → S(x l,f ) -mx l,f → S(0) equals 0 or µx l,f → S. Hence, we denote {vA xS l,f } Z 0-z ,N as the message set of µx l,f → S. And it means that the minimum message passing to the S node is from x l,f . In addition, the subchannel assignment for x l,f is strictly limited in the subchannel set Z 0-z . This set denotes the entire subchannel set Z 0 eliminates the subchannel z. Similarly, based on Eq. ( 36), if x j,z = 0, we can define {vB xS l,f } Z 0 ,N as well, reflecting the assignment factor x l,f is valid for all Z 0 subchannels. Since Z 0 ={z}∪Z 0-z , the sums of the denoted messages for µx l,f → S can be decomposed as in Eq. (37).
div.formula: N l=1 f ∈Z 0 vB xS l,f = N l=1 f ∈Z 0-z vB xS l,f + N l=1,l =j vB xS l,z = N l=1 f ∈Z 0-z vA xS l,f + N l=1,l =j vB xS l,z .(37)
div.p: Considering that one subchannel can only be assigned to at most one SU, it is reasonably determined that
div.formula: N l=1,l =j vB xS l,z = min l =j µx l,z → S,(38)
div.p: As a result, for j = 1, . . . , N +1, the normalized message from the node S to the node x j,z can be computed as:
div.formula: µS → x j,z = -min l =j,l =N +1 µx l,z → S j = N + 1 0 j = N + 1.(39)
div.p: In conclusion, according to the marginal theory in [40], the marginalization of x j,z can be computed as:
div.formula: τ j,z = µW j → x j,z + µC z → x j,z + µS → x j,z ,(40)
div.p: and the value of x j,z can be determined according to:
div.formula: x j,z = 1 ifτ j,z < 0 0 otherwise.(41)
div.p: To implement MPA for computing the optimal RA results, the marginal messages need to be calculated iteratively as τ j,z (t). The iterations will stop once all the assignment factors
Accordingly, the final allocation result is determined as
Step 3. Access control.
Once the allocation result is achieved, it is necessary to consider the possible outages.

For the first place, as mentioned in the power initialization step, if the number of accessible subchannels is not sufficient, the secondary resource will be allocated with harmful interference to PUs. At this time, the harmful SUs need to be rejected to access the primary subchannels.Secondly, in the proposed scheme, the power threshold P max is not considered in the power budget related message. Therefore, the total power allocated may be unaffordable, causing an outage to the RA. However, from the corresponding message formulations it is obvious that the total power consumption has already been suppressed greatly. Therefore, this kind of outage can be avoided through presetting an appropriate power threshold. For example, the power threshold can be preset according to the number of request SUs and the affordable power of the SBS, expressed as:
div.formula: P max = min N * P SU max , P SBS max .(44)
div.p: In Eq. (44), P SU max is a fined constant for each requiring SU, and P SU max is the maximum power affordable for the SBS. Once the outages occur, a heuristic access control strategy is considered by us to reject unsuitable access and ensure harmless access effectively. For the inaccessible subchannel assignments, all the corresponding SUs will be rejected directly. Then, the total power needed can be recomputed according to the power initialization of the admitted SUs. Then, if the the powerrelated outage still occurs, the SUs with the most power demands will be rejected one by one until the power budget constraint can be satisfied. IV. DEEP LEARNING-BASED D3D-MPA IMPLEMENTATION Since there are loops in the factor graph, it is difficult for MPA to converge in applications. Especially, in our 3D graphbased MPA, the loops are more complicated. To solve this problem, we proposed a damped 3D MPA based strategy to make the original MPA convergent effectively and efficiently, with the help of deep learning.

div.head: A. Damped 3D messages formulation
div.p: Based on the previous works on the damped (reweighted) 2D-MPA in [31][32][33][34][35][36][37][38] and the messages in our 3D factor graph, the damped 3D message can be formulated as in Eqs. (45-47).
div.formula: µW j → x j,z = ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z -ε 1 {µx j,f → W f + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f } Z1 + (1 -ε 1 )(ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z + µC z → x j,z + µS → x j,z ),(45)
µC z → x j,z = -ε 2 min l =j µx l,z → C z -(1 -ε 2 )(µW j → x j,z + µS → x j,z ), (46
) µS → x j,z =          -ε 3 min l =j,l =N +1 µx l,z → S -(1 -ε 3 )(µW j → x j,z +µC z → x j,z ), j = N + 1 0, j = N + 1.(47)
div.p: To achieve the optimal values of the damped parameters, we apply deep learning to the D3D-MPA based RA scheme, via unfolding the iterations as a multi-layered neural network. Through learning from the sampled RA results, the optimal parameters can be obtained in real time.

div.head: B. Resource allocation-based feed-forward neural network
div.p: Similar to [30], the feed-forward part of the neural network for the learning based MPA can be constructed in Fig. 3. The input data set y is the RA request information of the SUs, including the sensing results of the subchannels, the initialized power and the weights for EE+SE tradeoff. Through the utility function module UF, the weighted interference term is computed. The vectors ε = {ε 1 , ε 2 , ε 3 } are the damped parameter sets on each layer, where ε (0) is the set of initial parameters. As a result, through the linear transformations in layers, the normalized message sets µ from function nodes to the variable nodes can be evolved, expressed as Furthermore, one layer of the neural network can be illustrated as in Fig. 4, where the nonlinear nodes A and B are related to sorting operations and selective input aggregations.
div.formula: µ t = {µ (t) W j → x j,z , µ (t) C z → x j,z , µ (t) S → x j,z }. (48)
y = {ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z },(49)
div.p: where µ / ∈j,z t-1 is the bypassing message sets for the variable node x j,z , expressed as:
div.formula: µ / ∈j,z t-1 = µ (t-1) W j → x j,f , µ (t-1) C z → x l,z , µ (t-1) S → x l,z ,(51)
div.p: for l = j and f = z. Importantly, in order to determine the convergence, the marginalization set for all the variable nodes is designed as the branching output τ (t), written as
div.formula: τ (t) = τ (t) j,z
div.p: = {µ (t) W j → x j,z + µ (t) C z → x j,z + µ (t) S → x j,z }.

(52) Through the unfolded neural network, we can clearly observe that when the number of the total layers is large enough, the D3D-MPA will experience oscillation and convergence. After the D3D-MPA converge at the T * th layer, the left layered message passing is redundant. With equations, the oscillating, convergent and redundant layers can be depicted as sgn τ
div.formula: (T * -1) j,z = sgn τ (T * ) j,z = sgn τ (T * +1) j,z = ••• = sgn τ (T -1) j,z = sgn τ (T ) j,z ,(53)

div.head: C. ABP-based Learning method
div.p: Since the D3D-MPA based feed-back neural network has been achieved, in this part we propose the ABP algorithm to learn the optimal parameters of our RA scheme. In order to learn the optimal iteration times T , mapped as the optimal neural network layers here, we define a cost function T W as:

According to Fig. 3, T is the number of total layers, and T * is the minimum number of convergent layers. Thus, T W is the redundant layers of the feed-forward network. According to Eq. (54), T W can be counted layer-by-layer from the last layer, i.e. the T th layer, backward along the feed-back network. Since the mechanism of counting T W is similar to the back propagation (BP) algorithm, we name it the Analogous Back Propagation Algorithm.

div.head: D. Stepwise ε learning
div.p: For the damp parameters ε(i) in the i th training, once the number of redundant layers T W (ε(i)) is counted, the corresponding convergent layers T * can be computed as:
div.formula: T * (ε(i)) = T -T W (ε(i)).
div.p: Accordingly, the learning target for the optimal ε is equivalent to minimizing the convergent layers:
div.formula: ε opt = arg min ε(i) {T * (ε(i))}. (56
div.p: It has been proved in [39] that, the values of damped parameters are continuous positive number, from 0 to 1, while the number of layers is a positive integer. As a result, the derivation-based back propagation algorithm for traditional deep learning can not be applied directly for RA learning. Therefore, the gradient approximation in our ABP algorithm for parameter learning will be implemented with a discontinuous expression as:
Correspondingly, according to the parameter learning algorithms in [30] and [31], the optimal ε can be searched with an approximate gradient descent as:
where η ε is the learning rate.
In order to learn all the optimal values of ε 1 , ε 2 , and ε 3 on each layer, a stepwise method with "pre-training and finetuning" is proposed for learning the parameters as below.

Step 1. Weight sharing-based pre-training: Tied ε learning Firstly, we assume that the damped parameters are same for all messages, which means that ε 1 = ε 2 = ε 3 = ε Tied . Then, learning the parameter vector ε will be simplified as a single parameter ε Tied pre-training. The optimal value can be trained iteratively based on the approximate gradient descent as
div.formula: ε Tied (i + 1) = ε Tied (i) + ∆ε Tied (i) = ε Tied (i) + η ε T * (ε Tied (i)) -T * (ε Tied (i -1)) ε Tied (i) -ε Tied (i -1).
div.p: (59) When the gradient does not descend any longer, determined by
div.formula: T * (ε Tied (i)) -T * (ε Tied (i -1)) = 0,(60)
div.p: the pre-training is completed. The corresponding pseudo code is summarized in Algorithm 1.
Step 2. Partial weight sharing based fine-tuning: Untied ε learning

Based on the pre-trained values, the three different kinds of damped parameters are better tuned successively in this step. The pseudo code is depicted as in Algorithm 2, where the detailed algorithms can be similarly deduced from Algorithm 1.
Step 3. Heuristic-based adaption: Layered ε adjusting Algorithm 1 The learning algorithm for pre-training ε Tied .

Input: Sequential RA requests numbered as i=0,1,. . . ,K, initialized step size ∆ε Tied (0) Output: ε opt Tied . 1: Set ε Tied (0) = 0 and T * (ε Tied (0)) = T ; 2: While Eq. ( 60) is not satisfied do: 3: Apply ε Tied (i) for D3D-MP based RA scheme to obtain optimal results; 4: Counting T W (ε Tied (i)) with the ABP algorithm; 5: Calculate T * (ε Tied (i)) as in Eq. ( 55); 6: Update the step size as in Eq. (58); 7: Update ε Tied (i + 1) as in Eq. ( 59); 8: End Algorithm 2 The learning algorithm for fine-tuning ε 1 , ε 2 and ε 3 . Input: The pre-trained ε opt Tied , initialized step size ∆ε
div.formula: 1 (0) = ∆ε 2 (0) = ∆ε 3 (0) Output: the fine-tuned ε opt-re = (ε opt-re 1 , ε opt-re 2 , ε opt-re 3 ) 1: Set ε 1 (0) = ε 2 (0) = ε 3 (0) = ε opt Tied and T * (ε 1 (0), ε 2 (0), ε 3 (0)) = T 2: Learn ε opt 1 with ε 2 = ε 2 (0), ε 3 = ε 3 (0) similar to learning ε Tied 3: Learn ε opt 2 with ε 1 = ε opt 1 , ε 3 = ε 3 (0) similarly; 4: Learn ε opt 3 with ε 1 = ε opt 1 , ε 2 = ε opt 2 similarly; 5: Re-learn ε opt-re 1 with ε 2 = ε opt 2 , ε 3 = ε opt 3 ; 6: Re-learn ε opt-re 2 with ε 1 = ε opt-re 1 , ε 3 = ε opt-re 3 ; 7: Re-learn ε opt-re 3 with ε 1 = ε opt-re 1 , ε 2 = ε opt-re 2 .
div.p: Furthermore, since the D3D-MPA is very complicated with numerous edges and various loops,it is necessary to set different damped parameters for different layers, representing the adaptive step sizes for searching the optimal RA result. Meanwhile, according to Fig. 3 in [38], if the damped parameters are too large, it is inefficient to address the loops of the factor graph, resulting in more oscillating iterations. While if the damped parameters are too small, the messages will be updated slowly, resulting in more searching iterations. As a result, appropriate layered parameters are necessary for performing the D3D-MPA effectively and efficiently. However, for each layer, it is difficult to formulate a cost function for learning the layered parameters individually. In this paper, we design a heuristic method through adjusting the layered damped parameters based on their corresponding marginalization. Similar to the branching output τ (t) in Eq. ( 52), the intermediate RA result of subchannel z after t layers can be analyzed based on the partial branching outputs on subchannel z

Based on the branching output for assigning subchannel on the t th layer, the current weighted interference introduced on subchannel z can be computed as: where x (t) j,z can be computed with Eq. ( 41) and Eq. ( 52). Then the layered damped parameters can be adjusted according to:
div.formula: W I (t) z = N +1 j=1 ρ z ϕ j ω j,z g j,z P S * j,z x (t) j,z ,(62)
div.p: where ε (t) 1,2,3 (z) is the t th layered parameters for x j,z , and ∆ε is a preset step size.

According to the three steps above, the evolution for ε learning is summarized as tied, message-based and layerbased. The former two types are learnt through sequential training, while the last type can be adjusted according to the intermediate convergence after the former two types are fine tuned.

div.head: E. Optimal T learning
div.p: Once the optimal ε is learnt, the RA scheme will converge to optimal results quickly. From Fig. 3, the optimal number of layers of the D3D-MPA based neural network T is
div.formula: T opt (ε opt ) = min{T (ε opt )} = T * (ε opt ).(64)
div.p: With the proposed ABP algorithm, it can be computed as
div.formula: T opt = T -T W (ε opt ).(65)
div.p: In summary, the proposed deep learning based RA scheme is illustrated as a flow chart in Fig. 5.

div.head: V. COST-EFFICIENT LEARNING-BASED MP ALGORITHM
div.p: In this section, we provide a simplified algorithm for the WIM based RA scheme, with a probability of allocating resource suboptimally. By means of traditional 2D-MPA and a neural network mapping, the original problem is decoupled as a tied ε learning based RA with a double thresholds based access control. The detailed analysis is depicted as follows. A. D2D-MPA based RA scheme with deep learning Firstly, we assume that the power budget constraint has been satisfied. Then, the original problem (P2) can be rewritten as:
div.formula: P3 : min Z 0 z=1 N +1 j=1 ρ z ϕ j ω j,z g j,z P S * j,z x j,z s. t. Z 0 z=1 x j,z = Z j , ∀j (C1 ) N +1 j=1 x j,z ≤ 1, ∀z (C2 ) N +1 j=1 Z j = Z 0 ,(C4 ).
div.p: Therefore, similar to Fig. 2 in [38], the normalized factor graph of (P3) can be presented as in Fig. 6. In Fig. 6, the request SUs are denoted by circles while the subchannels are denoted by squares. Compared with the D3D-MPA, the 2D factor graph is not so complicated and the convergence speed is relatively high. Moreover, the corresponding damped messages can also be derived similarly as:
div.formula: µ (t+1) j,z = ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z -ε 2D Tied {µ (t) f,j + ρ f ϕ j ω j,f I S * j,f } Z1 + (1 -ε 2D Tied )(ρ z ϕ j ω j,z I S * j,z + µ (t) z,j ),(66) µ
(t+1) z,j = -ε 2D Tied min l =j µ (t+1) l,z -(1 -ε 2D Tied )µ (t+1) j,z ,(67)
div.p: x
div.formula: (t+1) j,z = 1, ifτ (t+1) j,z < 0 0, otherwise,(69)
div.p: where ε 2D Tied is the unified damped parameter for the 2D message formulations. As a result, the pseudo code for the simplified D2D-MPA is written as in Algorithm 3.

For implementing the D2D-MPA based RA scheme with deep learning, the corresponding neural network is depicted as in Fig. 7. We assume that the D2D-MPA outputs an optimal assignment result within T * times of iterations, The damped Algorithm 3 The D2D-MPA for resource allocation. Input: Sequential RA requests y(i) = {ρ z , ϕ j , ω j,z , I S * j,z }, the learnt parameter ε 2D Tied ; Output: xj,z 1: Set µ z,j (0) = 0, x j,z (0) = 0; 2: While x j,z (t + 1) = x j,z (t) do: 3: Each SU j sends messages µ j,z (t + 1) as in Eq. (66) to the SBS; 4: The SBS sends messages µ z,j (t+1) as in Eq. (67) to each SU; 5: Each SU j computes marginal τ j,z (t + 1) and x j,z (t + 1) as in Eqs. (68-69); 6: End while messages passed layer by layer for 2T * times and output the optimal RA results.
In addition, to learn the parameters ε 2D Tied and T * , similar learning algorithms can be deduced based on the approximate gradient descent and ABP algorithm.

div.head: B. Access control
div.p: When the optimal result for (P3) is achieved, the interference and power constraints should be checked. If the are satisfied, the RA result of (P3) is the final and optimal solution. Otherwise, a double thresholds-based access strategy is considered, similar to the step 3 in Section IV. Firstly, for subchannel z, if it is assigned to SU j with P S * j,z , and the interference introduced is larger than the threshold, the SU j will be refused access to any subchannels. Then, the total power consumed by the admitted SUs is computed as
div.formula: P AC total = j∈SU AC Z 0 z=1 xj,z P S * j,z , ∀j,(70)
div.p: where SU AC composed of the admitted SUs left. Secondly, P AC total should be checked for the power budget as: P AC total ≤ P max = min N * P SU max , P SBS max .
If the criterion fails to be satisfied, the access control will be executed through excluding the SUs with the highest power allocated one by one.

div.head: VI. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this section, we provide the simulation results and corresponding analysis to verify our learning based RA scheme. In detail, we mainly focus on the simulations for the D2D-MPA, while the conclusions for the D3D-MPA can be similarly achieved based on the analysis below.

For start, the same scenario is considered here as in our previous paper [31]. As a result, the values of the communication parameters are omitted in this section, unless they are especially in our simulations here. Additionally, the weights on each secondary interference are all considered as:

Firstly, we investigate the simulated performance on the efficiency tradeoff effects of our proposed WIM based RA scheme. In Figs. 8-11, we compare the performances of the proposed WIM scheme to those of the previous scheme IM and the traditional scheme PM with different SINR demands. For Fig. 8 proposed here with strict rate constraints is denoted as the hard AC strategy, while the one in our previous work that considers the SUs with compromising rate demands is denoted as the soft AC strategy. In Fig. 8, we find that the total power allocated in the WIM scheme is not too much larger than the minimum one consumed in the PM scheme, compared with that in the IM scheme. Additionally, the performance of the total power is almost unchanged as the access control scheme and the primary SINR target changed. This is because the power is allocated according to the secondary SINR demands. When the secondary SINR is relatively low, the primary SINR demands and the access scheme hardly affect the secondary power allocations. However, when the primary SINR target gets larger, more subchannels are unsuitable for the SUs and more SUs are rejected to access the subchannels under the hard-AC schemes. As a result, the secondary total power will become lower when the primary SINR gets larger, especially for the hard AC scheme. Thus, it is confirmed that the SUs can access the licensed spectrums with lower power by using the WIM scheme. At the same time, the primary capacity is better preserved as well, which is verified by Fig. 9. Combining the two conclusions, it is verified that through introducing the weights on the secondary interference, the power consumption of the SUs and the sum rate of the PUs are jointly considered with a performance tradeoff. Since the primary power transmitted, secondary power budget and the available subchannels are fixed in real scenarios, it is definitely true that both the SE+EE for the SUs and the PUs are improved with a tradeoff among them. Additionally, the hard-AC refuses more SUs, which reduces the secondary interference more effectively and Through Figs. 10-11, the performance of both the primary and secondary systems is simulated via changing the secondary SINR target and the PSD of noise. For these simulations, the primary SINR target is set as 20 dB, and the hard-AC is adopted. From Fig. 10 it is observed that the SUs access the primary system with lower power consumptions via the proposed WIM scheme, especially when the noise power is high. Similar to the performance comparison in Fig. 9, the corresponding capacity of the PUs is also considerably high with the WIM, as shown in Fig. 11. In Fig. 12, the effects of the total available subchannels' number Z 0 on the secondary power consumption is investigated in the WIM scheme. Moreover, the conditions that various SUs demand different numbers of subchannels are considered. In detail, 4 8 SUs are considered, with 2 and 4 subchannels for per SU. From the simulated results, it is seen that higher rate demands and more request SUs will introduce higher power consumption. However, these effects are alleviated by providing an adequate number of subchannels for assignment, because more available subchannels bring more accessible subchannels for the SUs to choose. Therefore, lower power is needed to satisfy the secondary SINR target. Besides, the simulation result for the effect of the available subchannels' number on the sum interference is almost the same as that in Fig. 12, based on the same reason analyzed as above. Thus, it is easy to infer that adequate number of subchannels for assignment improves both the capacity of SUs and PUs, correspondingly improves the EE of SUs and the SE of both SUs and PUs.

In summary, through analyzing the effects of the different schemes on both the primary and secondary system performance, it is verified that the proposed WIM scheme provides the SUs with satisfying RA, Accordingly, the capacities and EE+SE for the SUs and PUs are higher with the WIM scheme.

After the performance simulations for the proposed WIM scheme on the EE+SE tradeoff between the PUs and the SUs, the performance of the proposed deep learning is simulated as well, as shown in Figs. 13-14. Firstly, the convergence performance of the three schemes with different RA requirements and dynamic damped parameters is plotted in Fig. 13. To observe the curves more clearly, the maximum number for iterative message passing is assumed as 26. From this figure, it is concluded that, for different schemes with fixed requirements, the optimal ε 2D Tied is unchanged. However, for the different transmitting requirements, the optimal damped parameters need to be When the optimal 2D damped parameter ε 2D Tied is learnt, the optimal iterative times T * , also known as half of the optimal layers for the corresponding neural network, can be investigated. In Fig. 14, the iterative times for both the optimal WIM scheme and the original WIM scheme (i.e. ε 2D Tied = 1) with different numbers of available subchannels are simulated. For the original scheme, it is shown that increasing the number of available subchannels helps to reduce the iterative times and the neural network layers. However, for the optimal scheme, the optimal iterative times and layers are always constants, no matter how the number of subchannels changes.In addition, it is found that, both more SU requests and higher rate demands will introduce more neural network layers to achieve convergent RA results.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: In this paper, we have proposed an energy efficiency and spectrum efficiency (EE+SE) tradeoff based resource allocation scheme aimed at minimizing the weighed sum of the secondary interference power. Due to the NP-hardness of the resource allocation problem, a 3D message-passing algorithm is presented. To apply the proposed 3D-MP algorithm more flexibly, a user virtualization strategy are considered. To tackle the convergence of the algorithm, damped parameters are utilized for the message formulations. To improve the optimality and convergence of the D3D-MPA based resource allocation scheme, a neural network-based deep learning scheme is introduced. Through the analogous back propagation algorithm, Additionally, an efficient D2D-MPA based RA scheme with a low learning cost is provided alternatively. The simulation results show that the proposed WIM scheme helps the SUs access the licensed spectrum with low power consumptions. Importantly, it can significantly preserve the capacity of the Compared with the similar schemes in the previous work, the WIM scheme has excellent and flexible performance in terms of the EE+SE tradeoff between the SUs and the PUs. Moreover, this deep learning based scheme obviously improves the optimality and convergence of the RA solutions for the SUs.
